title: Unicode Key Labels for X-Keys Input Devices

description.text:
OK, this is uber-niche, and if it helps 1 other person I'll be utterly shocked, but here we go...

Quick background: I sell magazines on eBay and sell just enough Spanish-language ones that I was looking for a convenient way to enter unicode characters such as accented vowels and "ñ"s. After trying a few on-screen keyboards and even an Android app on my tablet, I finally broke down and bought an X-Keys, which is a fully-programmable secondary keyboard. It has a facility to print labels, but I thought it'd be nice to 3D print labels so that the light shines through the character, like my gaming keyboard does. Had to do some trial and error with this and finally got the top row containing accented vowels and Ñ. Tried a couple times to get the last two keys (¿ & ¡), but since they share the key with a shift-layer character it was beyond my printer's limits to cram so much in such a tiny space. I'll most likely upload the other rows as I make them. I have all the grave accents and some of the other lesser-used characters too, in addition to a hexadecimal pad (yeah I like to program too) and some arrow keys, and some macros to automate some of my eBay listings.

If it helps anyone and you want to reproduce what I did to suit your own purposes, here's the process I used in 123D Design:

  1. Create a box 13.5x13.5x.25
  2. Create text and extrude
  3. Drag text to the top of the box and sink it through
  4. Subtract the extruded text from the box
  5. Remember this needs to be in one piece, so things like As or Os will need a connector somewhere, so just add a box primitive. I started with 2x2x.25 and pushed/pulled a side as needed to make the bridge.
  6. If you had to add a connector, be sure to combine all.
  7. Export to STL.

Thank you NukeNRG, I have an X-keys 24 that I use for live streaming. When I get my printer in I will be using this to personalize my X-Keys

title: Smooth Rolling Ball Bearings using Airsoft BB's

description.text:
Make any project roll smoothly with these standardized bearings. Using 6mm Airsoft pellets as ball bearing, these roll smoothly, yet with very tight tolerances. Perfect for inserting into wheels, gears, ect. Just create a hole 10 mm deep with a diameter of 20 mm, 30 mm, or 40 mm and then pop one in!

Instructions:

Line up the hole on one side of the bearing and insert the appropriate number of bearings.
20 mm = 5 Bearings
30 mm =10 Bearings
40 mm = 15 Bearings
A little bit of WD-40 can help smooth things out

description.text: This is a replacement speedometer needle for my 1982 Subaru Brat DL. It should fit any EA81 Subaru DL (1980-84 for cars, 1982-84 for Brats). The low-end DL trim level cars and Brats had a different instrument layout than the higher-end GL models. The speedometer needle for the DL models is very thin, and after a few decades in the harsh sun of Southern Utah the needle in my Brat DL was very faded and warped. Perfect candidate for a 3D printed replica!

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Supports may need to be manually placed so they support the entire length of the needle (see picture). I recommend not placing supports too close to the middle pivot cylinder to allow for easy removal.
Remove raft and supports and grind down the back end so the length closely matches the original needle. The hole for the pin in the bottom may need boring out with a Dremel to fit on the speedometer.

I modeled this in Autodesk Maya 2016 based on the best measurements I could get from the original warped needle from my Brat. I designed it to be as close to the original as possible and I think it came out quite well.

description.text: This is a full size model. Use your slicer to scale it down to what ever size you want.

Happy year of the rooster!
Make your very own Lunar skin Mei hairpin from Overwatch.

If you want to use a pearl instead of the sphere halves included in the files, I've used the 25 mm sized bead. I did find that it was really tight to fit and 20 mm looked too small. If you can find a bead between those sizes, that'd be excellent. Otherwise, it just took a little sanding to fit the 25 mm pearl.

If you use this file to make your own pin, please send me pictures! I would love to see it and feature your photos. Email your photos to [email protected] I hope you enjoy this free file, and good luck with your project!

Measurements

Here are the sizes of the pieces included in the download. I do have a very large print area, so some pieces may need to be sliced to fit your machine of choice.

Needle length: 10.5 inches
Pin head height: 3 inches
Pin base width at largest part: 1.5 inches.

description.text:
Ideally, this should help route in-ear microphones through the main body, as well as allow the main body to be mounted on top of a camera. I also have another main_body that includes the nut hole from the original along with a male hot shoe. I'm not sure how sturdy that is as I can't print it.

I don't have access to a printer so I actually don't know if it works as intended, or if some parts are too fragile

I just made wedges and subtracted them from the parts that I wanted to expand.

To add the hot shoe, I added the "hotshoe.STL" file from jaygraco's piece to the bottom of the main body.

description.text:
Like my recent AA/AAA battery holder for when we travel this is for NB-5L's. The new Canon S100 (not to be confused with the old Canon S100) is a bit of a power hog so when traveling you need more than one battery, sometimes more than two batteries.
However after one battery they start to become hard to control in your pockets, purses, book bags, etc.
So this is parametric in that you can say how many batteries you want it to hold and the size and shape of each battery.
Tolerances are pretty tight so some fiddling may be in order.

Print... make sure your batteries fit... put batteries in.. put in pocket... take pictures knowing you will be able to find your batteries when you need them.
We also use a convention for knowing if a battery is charged: If the battery terminals are visible (i.e.: facing 'up') then the battery is charged.

author: ritzy

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hTGTHzLN20g

*Now Battery Powered! 5+ Hour Battery life!

Use Boost converter:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B011EBSKK0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Amazon - $7.76
And a RAVPOWER RP-PB41 Battery:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B012NIQG5E/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Amazon Prime - on Sale for 35$!
More Battery Info:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aVNQKss2Bwk

Re-Designed 6- Button Layout!

This is a ground-up Remix of malopezn's Arcade Cabinet.
Found Here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:768663
Big Thanks to malopezn for the initial Design, as it saved me a TON of time.

For this build I decided to use a Raspberry Pi3, High Def 10" Screen, 6 button Layout, NeoPixel lighting, an Arduino Nano, and a Pimoroni Picade parts kit.

This still prints on any 200x200x160+ Prusa or better, and for the most part does not need any support. The Light Frames do need support for the parts touching the Bed plate.

So Far I have added the Following to the design:

Refit Location for the Raspberry PI 2/3 (Removed B Model Mounting)
Added Mounting for the HDMI Screen Controller Board
Added Mounting Area for the HDMI Screen Control Board and IR LED
New ATX Molex Power Supply Cut Out
Added a Cut out to Wire LED Strip into the Cabinet Marquis
Inserts for the Cabinet Marquis (White or Clear, Painted Letters, Accented by LED Strips)
Added Glue-On Printable Decals (Pac-Style)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:681851
Refitted to use a Pimoroni Picade KIT (Exact Fit)
Speaker mounting added (For Picade Kit Speaker - Exact Fit)
Slotted mounting where possible to make fitment more flexible
Holes added to Left Upright, to allow LCD driver board screws to be reached easily.
10" Screen frame added. allows you to make the 10" LCD into a more hearty assembly.
Switched to Magnetic Mounting for screen, for easy service and card swaps.

Possible Upgrades Still to Be Implemented:
Nanopixel Illuminated Buttons
Sound Reactive Buttons and Marquee
On/Off switch for Marquee
Portable Lithium Battery Power and Charging (Implemented, See Above!)
Coin Slot
Trackball or Ergo Trackpad
Water or Peltier Cooling for Overclocking the PI.
Illuminated Side Panel Decals
And So much room for more in this little guy :-)
Customize to your hearts desire, All Design Files Included!

Build Parts List:

x2 Rolls of PLA or ABS Plastic, Plus a little bit of CLEAR for the Marquee.

10" HDMI Screen 1280 x 800 (Non-Touch) - $76.00 + Shipping
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00S4EWF6G/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Molex 5 AMP Power Supply - $18.00 + Shipping (Comes with a SATA to USB Kit)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01GVB8YEA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
OR
https://www.amazon.com/Electop-Drive-Adapter-Converter-External/dp/B01LYL3G0O/ref=pd_sbs_147_11?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=B01LYL3G0O&pd_rd_r=D45PK4WGQ4SZNADQQK0T&pd_rd_w=bci5T&pd_rd_wg=8d3W5&psc=1&refRID=D45PK4WGQ4SZNADQQK0T
For only 10$, but you gotta wait a month to get it...
MUST be 2.5a/2.5a (5 Total Amps) or it will NOT be powerful enough to run the PI AND the screen! These are hard to source. One of the above units should do the trick!

Neopixel Type Lights - ($16.00)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01GYDLJ24/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

An Arduino Nano v3 Type, or Clone, to Control them with: (3$ - 10$)
All Over the Web
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00SGMEH7G/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
(Good Deal on 3 Clones that I Know work)

Raspberry PI3 ($35.00)
All over the Web

64gb Class10 Micro SD Card (20-25$)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B010Q588D4/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Pimironi Picade HAT Kit - $54.00 Shipped.
https://shop.pimoroni.com/products/picade-hat

Short HDMI Cable - $10 Average (I had one laying around)

Hardware Fasteners! Mix of 1/4" Nuts and Bolts should get you done. (Approx $15)
I used x2 hobby bolt packs from the hardware store.

Uses x4 Neodymium Magnets to hold the halves together. (Approx $10.00)
Magnets are 6.35mm x.6.35mm x 25.42mm N42 Strength. (37 lbs of Pull Force)
1/4" x 1/4" x 1"
https://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=B44X0

Glue. I use Loctite go2 Glue. As it Dries Perfectly Clear and is relatively strong. $5.00
http://www.midlandhardware.com/164309.html?gclid=Cj0KEQiAw_DEBRChnYiQ_562gsEBEiQA4LcsssCUvJgLsK9W-IvjbX9tngGxEL68p-Ndi5wT9aKHTpMaAjlc8P8HAQ

Also helpful to have:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0147YM3DG/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Circuit Project Plates
And
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LZF1ZSZ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Jumper Sets...
As they make the build WAY easier!

Approximate Kit Build Cost = $250-300 If you shop around, you can do even better...

This is a LONG build, and printing time is measured in days to weeks, depending on your machine... But its Worth it :-)

Basic Build Steps:

  1. Print out all parts. Including x4 Magnet Blocks, and the Marquee in CLEAR or White.

  2. Wire Up the Kit and Test all Parts, Using the guides Below to get your image working and controls set up.

  3. Start Cleaning up wire. Zip Ties and Twisting are what worked best for me.

  4. Start bonding all parts together.

  5. Mount all boards.

  6. Mount Screen into Frame.(After Cleaning the Supports VERY Well.
    (File the inside of the frame down if needed, if it presses in on the edges too hard it creates white distortions at the edge of the screen that will eventually cause damage)

  7. Glue in Magnet Blocks and Neodymium Magnets, Clamping them to Set 100% before any test fitting of the top and Bottom. Or it WILL pull the blocks out...

  8. Wire up the Arduino and Neopixel Lights. Wire their power up to the aaccessory 5v on the top of the picade, and the grounds to the right of that, also on the picade hat accessory area. (5-6 holes that are labeled for use on the face of the board itself)

  9. Program the Neopixels and test them.

  10. Do a full power up and down test once fully assembled. Check components for heat.

  11. Close up the unit and make sure ALL controls work by re-setting up the emulationstation controls.

  12. Set up a Mouse or Trackball for Missile command and the like...
    (Guides on the Web for this)

Then its.... GAME ON!

Light Controller How To:

https://create.arduino.cc/projecthub/whimsy-makerspace/arduino-compatible-nano-neopixel-controller-6f0c4b

How to Wire Up The PiCade HAT:

https://learn.pimoroni.com/tutorial/sandyj/getting-started-with-picade-hat

Detailed Adding Roms and DIY Attract Mode Setup and Config.

--->https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eYCPFO4lclA<---

Deans Attract Mode ShortCut Setup...

--->https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WtRsMrUWgu4&t=582s<---
Retropie Dean's Attract mode, Plus Picade HAT setup.
http://retromaniacus.com/gaming-front-ends/retropie/deans-gamestation-32gb/
MUST Signup through Facebook, All other signups are AUTO REJECTED!
Download Dean's Attract mode Image.
Flash to a 32GB+GB card using win32DiskImager
Edit the Config.txt file onthe boot partition before removing the key.
Change:
--> #framebuffer_width=1280
--> #framebuffer_height=720
to
framebuffer_width=1280
framebuffer_height=800
And Change:
dtparam=audio=on
to
--> #dtparam=audio=on
Then Save the File and remove the key.
Insert it into your PI3 and boot up.
Exit Attract mode with a keyboard using the escape key, as your buttons will not work yet.
At the Command Prompt type the following:
sudo dpkg-reconfigure keyboard-configuration
Setup a 101, English US, Defaults on the altgr and no compose key... (Make sure it all Says US and hit enter after that till its done and back at the command bar at the bottom. Basically)
Type: sudo reboot
Hit enter and wait for reboot
Exit Attract mode. (May have to force exit with CTRL-C at this point.)
(Plug in an Ethernet cable to the PI and to some internet for the next part)
At a command line type the following:
curl -sS https://get.pimoroni.com/picadehat | bash
Saying yes to the first option, so it runs (takes a little bit to run), and yes to the use speaker on the picade hat option.
You can say yes or no to the rom option. It has no bearing on sound or function.
Type: sudo reboot
Hit enter and wait for reboot.
You should hear sound.
Buttons and keys need to be setup.
ISSUE: MAME coin (Acting as keyboard Button "C" and is on the Front Left of the unit) is not working correctly in lr-mame2010 (Which is what Dean's Image uses)
Easy SOLUTION: Make changes to the picade hat default button profile to map C and S to NUM5 and NUM1
At a command line, type the following:
cd Pimoroni/picade/picade-hat/gamepads/
cp picadehat-default picadehat-backup
sudo vi picadehat-default
edit the following....
Under "Keys :{"
Change COIN to 5
and START to 1
:wq and exit
./configload picadehat-default
Say yes to Reboot.
Now go into Emulationstation, Retropie, and Retroarch.
Reset the Keys in the order of... Retroarch First, then Emulationstation, then Attract mode and Emulators.
If you go in that order you will have a less difficult time of it.
But no matter how you slice it, setting up Picade Buttons Sucks 

_____

Master Tip: When setting up buttons and testing key configurations, the command line in retropie, allows you to simply type "showkey" and it will briefly start showing you the results of joystick moves and button presses.
It stops on its own after about a minute. Re-Run it as many times as you like to make sure all your connections are working.

_____

Printer:

Folger Teck Prusa i3 Aluminum

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20mm - .16mm

Infill:

30+% Bottom and 25+% Top

Notes:

Additional Printing Considerations:

Screen Frame and Possibly one or two others may need supports, depending on your printer.

Screen Frame supports can be hard to remove... Be Patient and Bring your Xacto...

Most of the rest of it should NOT need supports.

You will NEED to print x4 of the Magnet Blocks in order to Glue them into place once you have your magnets glued into them.

The Fit on these is TIGHT for a reason. Neodymium magnets are VERY strong.

You need to make sure to Glue these into place and CLAMP them while they dry.

Suggestion: Do the BOTTOM, Let them Set 100%, then CHECK THE POLARITY of the magnets, and then set the top ones in and glue them, clamping them into place for setting.
(DOUBLE check your magnet polarity! Last thing you want is to do like I did and set the magnets in wrong the first time and have to pry them out and clean up the glue... It was not fun)

--------> Caution! <--------

Neodymium magnets are so strong that the "Clacking" they produce when coming together can shatter the magnets and cause sharp dust to fly off at high speeds!
ALWAYS use eye protection when working with N42 Magnets, as they can blind you without warning.
I Use Gorilla Tape as a Buffer Pad for them to come together on. It cushions the blow and prevents shattering Long Term.

----------------------------------

Finishing Up...

Bonding the Halves...

I used a mixture of hardware and Glue to bond the top 4 Cubes and the bottom 4 Cubes into a "Top" and "Bottom" assembly as I went along.

Be sure to Get the electronics figured out FIRST, and get the Joystick wired up correctly, before you start thinking about final assembly.

The Unit CAN be assembled after the halves are bonded, but its a royal pain in the rear end, unless you have tiny hands or flexible fingers...

Recommend Strongly the "Test as you go" approach. It will Save you Massive Time!

comments.text:
The Bottom 6 Pieces "should" fit within your print area. The Top 2, however, are about 165 to 175-ish long.
It is possible to shorten them in Sketchup, however, it would very much change the look of the unit.
I would have to completely eliminate the overhang above the screen.
Even with that, I am not 100% sure I could fit it into a space under 155.
I would have to start from scratch on the top portion and redesign it altogether.
Which normally i would be willing to do, but I am so busy with work at the moment, that it wont be possible for several months.
My best suggestion is to find a local makerspace, or have the top 2 pieces printed for you on a larger unit.
The rest, you should be able to check and see if they will fit your printer, by sizing Cura to your print area, and checking the STL files one by one.
Cura will grey out portions of 3D objects that are not within the set print area.

description.text:
Note!!!
this part broke after a few weeks of use - https://goo.gl/photos/5fpRg7m1fgBkHXUp9
I designed a much more rigid alternative - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2163117

This is part of a project in which I converted my longboard into an electric longboard for my kid. I mount 4S 5200mAh lipo on it for the kid, but it can hold 2 or even 3 packs stacked if you don't mind the hight. There is room for velcro straps on the sides, but those are not needed when mounting a single pack.

There are pros and cons for using LIPO over lithium-ion cells which are more often used, and there are pros and cons for mounting it on top of the board (instead of beneath it) . Keep those in mind when making a decision.

Pros:

  • Lipos are easier to source (when counting the spot-welding involved in li-ions, at least where I live), there are some bargains in stores like Hobbyking.
  • For those with RC background, charging, balancing and monitoring lipos is easy.
  • Since you can carry spares in your backpack, it is easy to create a lite and adaptive setup (both for different range and for different speeds)
  • Mounting on top means that you see the battery (if something happens to it).
  • Mounting on top makes cheap and simple monitoring easier (just hook a battery monitor).

Cons:

  • Lipos are much less safe than li-ion. (please understand this risk)
  • Lipos wear out much quicker
  • Mounting on top means you can trip on the battery
  • Mounting on top means you can step on the battery (You can design a top cover to avoid it)

description.text:
While I love my Aeropress it really didn't come with good storage. They provided a cloth bag which almost seemed worse than just chucking it into the cabinet.

So I put together this design. The funnel of the Aeropress snaps perfectly on to the top of the Aeropress itself. Once you've put those together they fit exactly into the middle of this holder. The scoop and stirrer then slot into the sides. There's just a little space under the Aeropress to allow airflow for drying. The bottom is closed to catch any drips. I've been using this for a few years now.

I eventually added a piece to the top to hold the filters. That's in the SVG file but not in the pictures. I'm too lazy to go back and take a new picture so you'll have to use your imagination.

description.text:
A corner bracket that is designed to fit inside an A3 shadow box frame and hold an LTN154AT09 LCD screen (obtained from an old Dell E5500 laptop). This bracket also has a screw hole in it that lets you affix one corner of a controller board to the bracket, keeping it (somewhat) in place.

If I keep going with making smart mirrors, I might convert it to a SCAD object so you can make your own.

Print four of these on a good quality setting. Put one in your frame, then slip the screen underneath. Put the second one in the opposite corner and sure the screen is straight and doesn't move. Put the last two in place, then put the back of the photo frame on. Gently shake the frame to ensure the screen is actually sitting in there tight.

description.text:
I came across an old play kitchen somebody was getting rid of. It had only one knob and was missing stickers. (Third pic) I created printable better-than-original replacement knobs and some burner stickers.
(Better than original, as in, each is held securely with two screws apiece so they won't work loose.) The best part about the way I designed this 'thing is that you don't need to have a plastic kitchen to start with. You can build a wood one, or even a simple cardboard box! (Second pic) Note: I have now completed and uploaded the second half of the kitchen - a sink faucet.

3d print the knobs.
I have single knob or sets of 4 or 5 knobs for convenience. The knobs consist of an inside and outside piece with the cardboard to go in between. (Note: the step part of the inside piece is a spacer so as not to crush the cardboard.) You'll have to drill out the screw pilot holes for whatever size screw you're using. 2d print the stickers.
To not waste any of the 8.5x11 sticker sheet I filled the rest of the page with "stainless steel" so you can decorate your kitchen further.

This version of the lego lightning bolt blade has the bolts split so that they can be printed in different colors and joined together. Other than the split it is identical to its predecessor, Lightning Blade 2.

There are two versions included: one with a linear split and the other with more of a triangular notch (version with S2 in the name). Each STL file has both sides of the split. So printing once in each color allows two "blades" to be made.  
So far the triangular notch version (S2) seems strong enough and less finicky for fitting: the linear notch has a tendency to print the notch more narrow than the prong resulting in too much stress from spreading. I haven't had any break yet, but I have also been judicious in which I attach.

Para identificar las llaves. Éste se hizo para probar la impresión en varios colores, introduciendo el comando "M600) en el fichero g-code con un editor txt. Como nuestra impresora soporta ese código, funcionó a la perfección. Al llevar al código, el extrusor se aparta, retrae el filamento, te avisa del cambio. Cambias el filamento y empieza ha extruirlo hasta que sale el color nuevo del filamento. Si ves que sigue saliendo el filamento anterior, te da la opción de extruir más filamento o Resume print para seguir con el nuevo filamento y terminar la pieza.
Traducción google:
To identify the keys. This was done to test the printing in various colors, by entering the command "M600" in the g-code file with a txt editor.As our printer supports that code, it worked perfectly.When carrying the code, the extruder moves away, If you see that the previous filament continues to come out, it gives you the option to extrude more filament or Resume print to continue with the new filament. Filament and finish the piece.

Notes:

Os pongo el g-code para que veais los demás parámetros, antes de la capa 12 introducimos el comando M600. Utilizo Slic3r, pero con el Repetier localicé la línea donde hacía el cambio de Z en la capa de inicio de las letras. Localizais la capa y la medida que os de, por ejemplo 2.1mm, le poneis en el buscador del editor de texto Z2.1, intercalais una línea antes de este código y simplemente poneis M600. Guardais el fichero y ya está hecho el cambio. Repito esto los soporta nuestra impresora.
Traducción google:
I put the g-code to see the other parameters, before layer 12 we enter the command M600. I use Slic3r, but with the Repetier I located the line where I made the Z change in the beginning layer of the letters. You locate the layer and measure it from, for example 2.1mm, you put it in the finder of the text editor Z2.1, intercalais a line before this code and simply put M600. You save the file and the change is already done. I repeat this is supported by our printer.

I have designed a holder for the Røde VideMic Pro that attaches to the cameras hot shoe mount. The original mic comes with a rubber band suspension, but the new model has a suspension much like this one.

This is a work in progress, this particular one fits the hot shoe screw from the original Røde mic suspension.
But I will upload some new redesigned parts in the near future. (For example: parts that fits another hot shoe adapter that can be bought cheap on eBay).

The model consists of:

1 x mic holder
2 x single rings (Thinner rings have more flex)
1 x stick for hot shoe (This part will be replaced in the future ).

They all fit together nicely, but you can glue them together to get a tighter fit and to avoid vibration noises.

title: Convert a Wanhao Duplicator i3 to MKSgen v1.1

description.text:
Arduino project and compiled binaries for using a mksgen board in a Wanhao Duplicator i3 v2.1 with Auto-Bed Leveling using a Servo-Probe

NO SUPPORT!
-You have to read and understand the sourcecode to make your own adaptions and customizations

Take Care!
I used a MKSgen v1.1 - do not know about differences on newer boards!
Also i changed the LCD to a "Reprap Discount full Graphics LCD Display": http://www.ebay.at/itm/332097287644 - did not get the original Display included in Marlin - phps i broke it - gave up

Baseplate: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1853712
Servoprobe: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2068839

Take Care, the Pinouts on the Connectors of the MKSgen1.1 seems to be mirrored - you have to file down the nozzle on the connectors to turn it 180 degrees when connecting on the MKSgen1.1 board
The Display fits exactly in the housing - indeed the SD-slot is not acessible without modifications which i do not need - printing via Repetier-Host and USB

the Z-endstop is now used for the Probe
One of the Z-Axis Servos has to be rewired in parallel or with a extension board and a separate Stepper driver in parallel to the first Z-Axis servo.
-Simple Adapter Board Baseplate included

Auto Bed leveling is set to 9 Points
Initiate Auto Bed Leveling:
Heat build Plate
G28 for Homing
G29 for Auto Leveling

Update 2017-02-16:
Uploaded actual project and .hex files with the following changes:
Correct Value for Hotend Thermistor
PID Tune Parameters corrected
PID Tune for Heatbed activated and tuned - Be Aware: I do have 5mm cork Insulation under the Heatbed

Attached my Start G-Code if anyone needs it:

; Start code
G90 ; Absolute Positioning
G1 Z50 F{Z_TRAVEL_SPEED} ; //To prevent overheating of the ABL-System
M107 ; Turn off fan
{IF_EXT0}M104 T0 S110 ; Preheat Extruder to a save Time- Printing would start earlier
{IF_BED}M190 S{BED} ; Heat the Bed - Auto Bed Leveling should be done with a heated Bed :P
{IF_EXT0}M104 T0 S150 ; Preheat Extruder to a save Time- Printing would start earlier

G28 ; Home extruder
G29 ; Auto Bed Leveling
G1 X5 Y5 Z25 F3600

G90 ; Absolute positioning
M82 ; Extruder in absolute mode
;{IF_BED}M190 S{BED}
; Activate all used extruder
{IF_EXT0}M104 T0 S{TEMP0}
G92 E0 ; Reset extruder position
; Wait for all used extruders to reach temperature
{IF_EXT0}M109 T0 S{TEMP0}

description.text:
Pieza para el soporte que sujeta el capó del coche cuando está abierto. Como podéis ver en las fotos solo he hecho una parte. Las medidas hay que pulirlas un poco pero como el apaño lo hace por ahora me quedo satisfecho, aunque decir que al meter la pieza que bloque la varilla se partió la pieza, un poco de pegamento, una lima y encaje a lo bestia. Si lo hiciera otra vez no le hacia la forma curva, se la haría cuadrada, le quitaría la pieza de bloque ya que poniéndole un tornillito para bloquearla varilla sería suficiente y la parte que entra en la chapa del coche la haría como bloque, y si me apuráis una base para con un par de tornillitos para agarrar la pieza a la chapa. En el momento que esta pieza se rompa la diseñaré de nuevo. La expongo aquí para que tengáis una idea.
Traducción Google:
Part for the bracket that holds the hood of the car when it is open. As you can see in the photos I have only done a part. Hi!

I designed these calipers as a fun and useful project.

It has markings every 1 mm, so if you're in between you're measuring .5 mm. If you look closely it is even a bit more accurate ;). It has virtually no play; But that's also dependent on what print settings you're using. I've added 3 types of sliding jaws, all three of them featuring different detentions regarding the slider.

Type 1; .6mm "play'' (which I've used, and resulted in no play at all)
Type 2; .4mm "play"
Type 3; .2mm "play"

Please share your experiences and findings if you make one, i'd love to hear (and see) them!

P.S. I might make an inch version, let me know if you'd like that.

Cheers,

While it's a nice gift, be prepared: working with melted chocolate is a damn dirty and terribly tedious job.

This is a mold to produce chocolate with custom text engraved into. A nice gift designed for Valentine's Day. Open it in customizer (Open in Customizer button) to engrave your custom text!

The engraving is 0.6mm in height, so use an appropriate layer height: 0.3mm, 0.2mm, 0.15mm or 0.1mm. The shell's wall is 0.8mm thick (designed for 0.4mm nozzle diameter). The mold has two parts, printed together: the shell and an inner part. You should be able to break/separate them after printing (there's a 0.5mm gap between them).

Molding

  1. Put a plate into the refigerator, and leave it there to cool down.
  2. Melt the chocolate. Experts say you must not heat it above 33.8 Celsius.
  3. Put the inner part and the shell together. Pour the melted chocolate into it.
  4. Move it onto the cold plate in the refrigerator; leave it there for about 10 minutes while chocolate crystallises and hardens back. Let the chocolate side look upward to get nicer surface on the bottom (so leave in the same orientation as it was).
  5. When cooled down, grip the shell with your fingernails, and push the inner part gently until the chocolate pops out. Make sure not to brake the cold&rigid chocolate.
  6. By removing the inner part the engraved text reveals.
  7. Repeat. 90g chocolate it just enough for 3 hearts.

Butter: it makes the separation easier, but you'll end up better surface finish without it. Use it only if you have problems pushing the chocolate our of its shell.

title: Improve flexible filament feed davinci pro 1.0

description.text:
In the case of flexible filaments, there is the danger that it bends in the gap between the drive pinion and the filament hose, and the filament is no longer conveyed, but is jammed in the printer.

The adapter shortens the free space so that this effect is prevented. The xy position is not yet 100% correct, but the adapter works fine.

In addition, the standard bend of the hose should be removed just before the print head by straight-line positioning. I removed the cable ties and fixed the hose adapter with the clamp. The hose is then higher so that it can rub against the cover. It is best to cover a cardboard in order to allow the hose to slide freely.

Bei flexiblem Filament besteht die Gefahr, dass es in der Lücke zwischen Antriebsritzel und Filamentschlauch biegt und das Filament nicht mehr gefördert wird, sondern sich im Drucker verklemmt.

Der Adapter verkürzt den freien Raum so dass dieser Effekt verhindert wird. Die xy Position ist noch nicht zu 100% richtig, aber der Adapter funktioniert prima.

Zusätzlich sollte der standardmäßige Knick des Schlauches kurz vor dem Druckkopf durch Geradestellen entfernt werden. Ich habe die Kabelbinder entfernt und den Schlauchadapter mit dem Klemmstück fixiert. Der Schlauch steht dann höher, so dass er gegen den Deckel reiben kann. Am besten eine entprechende Pappe unterkleben, damit der Schlauch frei gleiten kann.

Press the filament release lever and insert the adapter instead of the cover.

Best with a 2mm drill from the hose side then manually work the filament hole in the holder. The filament must be able to slide as easily as possible into the tube.

Den Filamentlösehebel drücken und den Adapter statt des Deckels einführen.

Am besten mit einem 2mm Bohrer von der Schlauchseite dann von Hand das Filamentloch im Halter nacharbeiten. Das Filament muss so leicht wie möglich in den Schlauch gleiten können.

author: art-enot

description.text: This is a simple pinhole lens and cap attachment for a Nikon camera with an f-mount bayonet style mount.

This was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6831 designed by xjcrawler01. I couldn't get this thing to fit, so I designed my own in openSCAD so I could tweak and reprint. This pinole lens fits on a Nikon camera (it worked on my D7000) like a regular lens. You affix a separately made pinhole over the small aperture using black electrical tape. A simple and easy, but very good pinhole can be made by the "beer can" method. The parametric OpenSCAD files are included, along with some dependencies to use rotate_extrude to make arcs, and dependencies to make the Nikon male f-style bayonet mount. I also included the dependency for an female f-style bayonet mount. With this, and a little ingenuity, you could make extender tubes for a homemade macro lens, for instance. I will try to knock one of those up soon. I tested both mounts with my lens and camera. The designs come from my measurements, so you might need to tweek/sand a little for your camera. "Beer can" method to make a pinhole
There is lots of good stuff on this on the web, so do a search. The basic method is to use a piece of aluminum from a beer can (say 1 cm x 1 cm). Use a punch or nail to make a small dent in the aluminum. Then sand the high side of the dent until a hole forms. To take a picture
Put the camera on a tripod or table. Set the camera to manual, ISO to 100 or 200, and exposure time to 0.5 seconds if in bright sun, 2 or more seconds indoors. Better to use a remote if you have one. Adjust the exposure time and camera position until you get a picture you like. There are tons of great resources on the web. So explore and enjoy!
Cameras are expensive, and this is not an authorized Nikon accessory. If you decide to print this thing, you use it at your own risk.

comments.text: Pin hole cameras are used a lot in model photography, like model railroads.  The infinite depth of field gives the photograph a very real appearance.
comments.author: MdLaFond

comments.text: I didn't know that, but it makes sense. Thanks for comment!
comments.author: MdLaFond

comments.text:
OK, just made one of these. Works, but somewhat difficult to fit.
Printed in PLA black to avoid internal reflections and works great.
comments.author: deuteragenie

comments.text: Looks like you could have better results if you reduced the glossy finish of the black ABS (black cardboard?) in the inside to avoid light reflections.
comments.author: aubenc

comments.text: I used PLA, which I think is a little shinier than ABS. But you are quite right, a less reflective material inside would be a lot better.
comments.author: aubenc

comments.text: Hmm, I don't get it - what's the benefit of a pin-hole lens like this?
comments.author: QuantumConcepts

comments.text: There really isn't a benefit for visible light images like this, beyond aesthetics and photography fun. Pinhole lens have very large depths of field, but they tend to be blurry. But it is a neat, physicsy way to make an image.
comments.author: QuantumConcepts

comments.text: I personally like to process the film however, I do see all the benefits of pinhole cameras without the need of having to do the "difficult" part.
comments.author: QuantumConcepts

description.text:
Wanted a solid holder for my Micro FPV Cams that allowed an easy and secure mount on my Crafts without the cam falling apart, usually the ringholders only hold the lenses but the board can come off making things very akward.
So this fits on the very famous micro cam mostly used as FPV cam, i love this tiny cam cause they are cheap , lightweight , small and the quality is good enough for the purpose, only had the flaw of not being easy to mount in a very efficient way and being fragile.

M2 hex socket cap screws
2Pcs M2X4mm
1Pcs M2X10mm
1Pcs M2 Hex nut
( got me this nice kit of screws https://goo.gl/oMCHZS )

I hope this will help you guys as much it did help me , wish you lot's of fun !

I won't have the electronics till tomorrow or Wednesday so I won't know if it works properly yet.

author: bozpet

description.text: Now on CubeHero to help me track changes as I try to fix it. https://cubehero.com/physibles/cymon/Folding_Knuckle_Duster_Ring I don't know why I'm so obsessed with making this work. Rogerlabs' original folding knuckle duster just didn't quite work for me. First of all there was a problem with the size. Then there was a problem with the joints. I fixed the first, but made the second both better and at the same time worse. This one is unitized so you can scale it up to the size of the largest ring size on the finger you intend to wear it on. So if my finger is 22mm in diameter (as it happens to be) scale it up by 22 or 2200%. Then print, assemble, and fail to wear because the joints are too big for every day wear. My next job is to make the joints closer into the body of the ring. But, hey, you get into a fight with this thing on your hand and I guarantee the other guy will be hating life. After all, this is ABS, the same plastic LEGOs are made out of. This is like stepping on a LEGO, right across your face. If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays

description.text: tl 1

This is a lens hood for the Helios 44m 7 58mm f2.
I use it on my Sony a6000 with a speed booster adapter. This gives me the full field of view of the lens not a croped view (plus it gives me extra stop).
So I designed the hood with the following in mind :

  1. To work with the full field of view (no vignetting)
  2. You can put it upside down to make it compact - store it with the lens.

Note.
The length is for a Helios lens with an adapter or speed booster.
If you have the lens with no or smaller adater you cant pout it upside down .

0,3mm or better

author: The_Chef

description.text:
I bought a cheap printer off ebay, CTC clone, Geeetech, 5 mm plywood. The X axis idler/tensioner self destructed - see photos.
The difficulty with this part is inserting the combination of bearings, pulley and shaft into a single piece of plastic without moving the pulley on the shaft. On my example the pulley won't move and I am reluctant to use much force.

Following design [2] I initially split the part horizontally into two pieces. The split line is slightly above the centre of the bearings and as a result they snap into the bottom part.

For the second version (files suffixed 2) I used a couple of small self tapping screws (1.7 mm thread x 7 mm thread length) to hold the two pieces together.

For the fifth version (files suffixed 5) I split the part vertically into three pieces and used the tensioning bolt and an extra M3 nut to hold it together. The middle piece has a slot allowing it to move outwards for the shaft to be inserted and the back piece has a peg to lock the middle piece in place when the nut is tightened. This version prints well and is the best solution.

Eventually I learnt that idler pulleys that run off centre can affect print quality and replaced the pulley that came with the machine with a metal one. Version six of the tensioner is for this type of pulley, no messing about with multiple parts, a simple axle through the bearing which is part of the pulley.

OpenSCAD source included.

Prior art:
[1] http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1830392
[2] http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2059238.

comments.text: What's the pulley on it?  Or how do you figure it out?
comments.author: joebywan

comments.text: The white nylon (?) pulley is the one that came with the printer - I had no luck finding them on ebay. I eventually bought "2pcs ∅5mm GT2 Timing Belt Aluminum Drive Idler Pulley w/ Bearing For 3D Printer" which is better.

description.text:
This is a modification of my previous upload of a 3-way symmetric joint example, mirroring the joint onto both ends of the shaft. The orientation of the joints allows for sliding 12 parts together to form a cube. 1/100 of an inch was shaved off the joint parts on the .stl file to allow for putting together without much, if any, post print filing.

The part was also creating in OpenSCAD and made customizable using the Customizer app. The length and widths of the shaft, along with the tolerance, can be modified to your liking. Check back soon for vphotos of assembled cube!

Also, don't forget to check out my other (non-mirrored) 3-way joint. It's a great demonstration piece, and it only requires 3 copies to be printed, instead of 12.

title: Carla Character from LEO the Maker Prince

description.text:
From the book LEO the Maker Prince:
http://www.leothemakerprince.com
http://www.amazon.com/LEO-Maker-Prince-Journeys-Printing/dp/1457183145
Carla had wanted to become an artist when she grew up. She became an accountant instead. Then Carla's calm life of numbers and "sense" was upended. She met LEO, the Maker Prince. And through LEO's magic, 3D printing, Carla finally became the artist she'd long ago wished to be.

Note - these files were updated on 2/7/15 to make them easier to print!
  • Print the black parts "digital_carla_blackParts..." (hair and shoes, eyes and eyeglasses) using black or a dark filament.
  • Print the white parts "digital_carla_whiteParts..." using white or a light filament. (The latest version of this file has been printed successfully on a Makerbot with no supports.)
  • Print the dress "digital_carla_dress..." using a color. (In the book illustrations, Carla's dress is orange! But you can add it to the black parts if you want to stick to 2 colors.)
  • Plug the shoes into the legs.
  • Plug the legs and shoes into the dress.
  • Plug the head and arms into the dress.
  • Plug the hair into the head and the eyes into the eye sockets.
  • Carefully place the eyeglasses onto the head. Look for small slots in the hair where the glasses can rest.
    • NOTE: All the parts except for the hair should be able to be printed with no supports.

comments.text: Any chance of getting the shoes as a separate file?  I've had some issues with them and don't want to reprint hair just to get shoes.
comments.author: hcpl_makerbot

comments.text: Yes, definitely. Thanks for asking!
comments.author: hcpl_makerbot

comments.text: Awesome!  Thanks much.
comments.author: leothemakerprince

comments.text: Hi! I'm so happy to hear your kind word about the project and I'm sorry to hear you're having trouble with the glasses.They are the most fragile part of the print for sure. I appreciate the feedback as I'm always trying to improve these files and in particular make them more robust. For the moment I can post a file of the glasses in different positions as that might help. If any other readers/printers have ideas please bring them on!
comments.author: leothemakerprince

comments.text: Thanks for the new upload. I will try that out. After I wrote my comment about the glasses, I proceeded to print the rest of Carla, and had similar problems getting a clean print in other areas, or being able to get supports off. Would you mind sharing the settings that you used? Thanks!
comments.author: leothemakerprince

comments.text: So sorry for the huge delay. I used an Afinia for many of these prints so the settings don't reflect that on other printers. I did use supports: 2 shells, 5mm area 4 lines space.
comments.author: pinallibraries

comments.text: Hello! Thank you so much for creating and posting these files. These characters are adorable, and the book was a great idea. I just started printing Carla, and so far her glasses are not working out for me. They are not coming out nearly as clean as the images I'm seeing posted here. Is everyone doing a lot of clean up? I'm using a MakerBot Replicator 2, 100% infill, 2 shells, standard temp and speed. Thanks for your suggestions!
comments.author: pinallibraries

comments.text: I am working on a collection / herding  game using these characters. Any chance of getting a Cat character designed? I would prefer if you did the design since  it would  be consistent in appearance with the  genre  you have created with these two characters. I  also do not know enough about design yet to be able to do it myself. I saw the hamster and figured a cat and mouse would be the next logical characters. We just got a tech hub in the Toronto reference library and am using this idea / things as a first project. As soon as I can consistently print these characters I am going to create several sheep (10 - 12) and a few Carla's (5 or 6) and hopefully a couple of cats! Play surface, Rule design and play testing is already in progress. Once the rules and play surface have been tested I will release them OS.
comments.author: Sundog1966

comments.text: Oh! The game sounds super cool! I'd love to see what you do with it. And yes, I can design a LEO-themed cat. It may take me a while. What is your timeline?
comments.author: Sundog1966

comments.text: I just printed two on my Replicator II, and they turned out terrific - with one exception. I used rafts and supports, which generally worked well. They snapped off nicely and cleaned up fairly easily. But I'm having real trouble getting the eyes to fit. Since they lie on their sides in the grouping, they end up with a fair amount of extra printed clutter that I'm having trouble cleaning to make fit.
comments.author: ThomF

comments.text: OK I revised the blackparts file. the eyes grow great now, and the glasses, too, as long as they come off the raft cleanly. The eyes are a little tricky in that they need to be rotated to the right position to fit in correctly. I can look into giving them a notch so they are oriented in one specific way. Thanks again for the feedback, and I can't wait to see what you make!
comments.author: ThomF

comments.text: Thanks ever so much. I'm printing now - will share the completed results soon.
comments.author: leothemakerprince

comments.text: Oh! I forgot I had exported the dress separately so that people could grow it in a different color if they wished. I've just re-uploaded. I also uploaded the eyes and glasses for the time being as a separate file if you want to try them. (Though I may remove them to avoid confusion.)
comments.author: ThomF

comments.text: One final comment/suggestion. The separate print file for the eyes and glasses is very helpful. In this orientation the both parts print clearly with a raft, which is easily removed.
comments.author: leothemakerprince

comments.text: I put some beefier glasses up there, though I think I could still use some more reinforcement on the hinge part.
comments.author: ThomF

comments.text: Ah, yes! The glasses are quite fragile little things. Your suggestions make a lot of sense.
comments.author: ThomF

comments.text: Awesome! I appreciate all of the effort you are putting into this - I know your followers will be delighted!
comments.author: leothemakerprince

comments.text: Hi ThomF, you are awesome! Thanks for the helpful suggestions! I will change that file and try your suggestions, and then repost to share with everyone.
comments.author: ThomF

comments.text: Hi there! Are you growing these parts with support material? Since they are curved parts they don't rest flat and require support. Is there a piece in particular that's causing the most trouble?
comments.author: leothemakerprince

comments.text: The white body parts don't work as parts are hanging in the air.  Any suggestions?
comments.author: khuttner

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3/Hesine M505 (Anet A8 compatible) x Carriage for E3Dv6 (Bowden)

title: ANET A8 | Customizable E3D v6 Carriage /  Bowden Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi Thingiverse-Community!



UPDATE March 27th: Added option for parameterizable sensor holder in CUSTOMIZER.

I was not satisfied with the stock hotend / extruder setup of the ANET A8! I had a couple of issues with the old one and I didn't like the following things:

  • Accessibility of the extruder motor was bad (unmount fan with cooling plate)
  • It was hard to actually watch the nozzle during print due to a clustered design with lots of components attached to the 'print-head'
  • High print speeds went along with more inaccurate results, due to the heavy 'print-head' with the extruder motor

The design is inspired / based on the design by Jubaleth (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2002778).



Features of this mount:

  • Slim, light and modular design
  • Unobstructed view on nozzle / as few things as possible in front of nozzle (cooling fan moved to left side, leveling sensor on back)
  • Equipped with several slots for zip ties for a proper cable management
  • Cooling fan in (nearly) same distance to the nozzle as before -> you have good chances to still use your current cooling duct
  • Fully compatible with x-axis cable chain (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2105040)
  • Customizable sensor holder (optional in customizer interface) - Attention: this sensor mount may interfere with other components (e.g. a cable chain), I still recommend the rear sensor holder (see links below)



Pick your version / file:

  • CarriageV2_3__63mm_AnetA8_E3Dv6_Mount.stl - For hotends with a total height of ~63mm (top to nozzle tip - measure without push-fit), eg. original E3Dv6
  • CarriageV2_3__74mm_AnetA8_E3Dv6_Mount.stl - For hotends with a total height of ~74mm (top to nozzle tip - measure without push-fit)
  • Use the CUSTOMIZER! - Just set your personal preferences and export your custom carriage! (Caution: settings in 'expert' tab are not foolproof and may need firmware adaptations (other then them in this description)!)

DISCLAIMER: There are several variations of hotends out there, I tried to adapt this carriage to the most of them! Nevertheless, in some cases the fan position might be slightly off. You can use the 'expert-fine-tuning' in the CUSTOMIZER to fine tune the position of the fan holder to suite you personal needs or to fit your beloved fan duct! (I used the same coordinate system orientation as the printer in order to make those adjustment parameters as easy graspable as possible.)



Modular extensions and recommended addons:

  • Bowden extruder motor mount (Anet A8 stock parts) or improved bowden extruder (non-stock parts)
  • Rear bed leveling sensor mount or rear sensor mount V2 (screw- and customizable)
  • Belt holder (by Simhopp)
  • Hotend cooling mount for the E3D v6 clones (by anthonywob)
  • Mistral 2 fan duct (by Leo) - rotate your heater block in a way that the shorter end points towards the fan



Firmware Adaptation:
Due to a changed nozzle position it is recommended to change the following parameter in your configuration.h file:
#define X_MIN_POS -10
NOTE: If this parameter is not changed, all prints will be shifted around 1 cm to the right.

If you added a sensor holder, you also have to adapt the probe position in the firmware correspondingly!



Why should I switch to a bowden setup?
A bowden setup has the benefit of moving the (heavy) extruder motor away from the moving carriage. Therefore the printer is able to accelerate way faster due to the reduced weight of the carriage. Based on this fact, the printer is able to achieve higher speeds without getting inaccurate results.



Why do you exchange the stock hotend with a E3D v6 styled one?
In order to avoid jams or clogges it is crucial to have a hot nozzle, but still a cold shaft! Compared to the stock version, E3D v6 styled nozzles provide a large cooling surface which will keep the shaft super cool without any effort!



Things you will need in order to switch to this setup:

  • E3Dv6 / E3D clone
  • Teflon tube and pneumatic couplers

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40

Quick Installation Guide

This is just a quick installation guide with some images for the basic steps.

Step 1: After unmoting stock metal frame, screw hotend mount with stock screws to the sliders. Step 2: Attach the belt tensioner / belt holder to the back of the mount with 6 screws. (OPTIONAL: Attach auto leveling sensor to the back as seen in the image) [Links to those parts can be found in the description] Step 3: Insert the hotend and secure it with the coresponding cap. Step 4: Attach the stock cooling fan with the stock screws to the side frame. Step 5: Attach cooling fan for hotend. Either use the one shipped with your hotend or print an adapter for the stock 40mm fan. [Corresponding links in the description] Step 6: Arrange your cables and fix them with zip ties

Changelog:

  • 02/12/17 - V2.0 - Initial (public) release
  • 02/13/17 - V2.1 - Smoother finish and slightly repositioned fan mount
  • 02/17/17 - V2.2 - Minor optical fixes
  • 02/19/17 - V2.3 - Fixes and optimizations in mesh export
  • 02/22/17 - V2.3 - Added Customizer support / version
  • 03/05/17 - V2.3 - Updated Customizer version (wider range fan z pos.)
  • 03/27/17 - V3.0 - Added option for sensor mount to customizer version

comments.text: So me and my father have been using this mount for our knock off E3D V6 from gearbest, and it was looking good, except during a lot of our prints the PLA would bind up somewhere in the E3D V6. We talked to some people and they said that it was a matter of the fins heating up and not getting cooled well. Sure enough, the fins were hot to the touch and the back part, the mount we printed, was also very warm. We have assumed this is the issue as the PLA becomes pliable within the V6 and were wondering if anyone else has had this issue and how did they resolve it?
comments.author: Gerengnick

comments.text: So we believe we found what the issue is, it seems in Cura the retraction settings were pulling the filament a whole 6.5mm! E3D says that a maximum of 5 is okay, which explains the binding in the heartbreak and the extreme heating of the fins. Now at 3mm we are doing well and the fins are just barely warm

comments.text: Is the front fan really necessary? I always thought it was meant to cool the stepper motor?
comments.author: derboehsevincent

comments.text: The fan mounted to the hotend is definitely required, because it ensures that just the nozzle is hot, while the shaft is kept cool. If the shaft would also heat up, the filament in it would jam and clog the hotend.

title: File case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Just a small case for the needle files to keep them together in the drawers, bags or wherever they might go. In the workshop or outside its essential to have all the tools organized.. Both parts of the case stay together by a friction fit, and we recommend printing in the orientation of the pictures. Scale or file to fit if necessary for your printer.

The needle files we designed this for are 140 mm long, and have a 50 mm long handle. The diameter of the handles are 3mm but the base have 4 mm holes. This allows for shrinkage if printed in ABS or a little wiggle room for variations in handle diameter. For files 140 mm long, pick the 120 mm long top.

I designed this thing to "stress" important aspects of 3D printing. You can use it to find where your printer fails and hopefully make adjustments to fix that problem. While my design is not scientific or calibrated, etc., it should help to test your printer in the following areas: Section 1, marked with "1," tests the accuracy of small perimeters and small infills (e.g. the "n" and "e"). Section 2 tests bridging. Section 3 tests taller extrusions as well as large inlays. Section 4 tests holes and arcs. Section 5 tests slopes. Section 6 tests peaks and super-small perimeters and infills.

title: 6 pc Metric Hex Wrench Holder (2mm to 6mm)

description.text:
Ok, it's all updated now... Should print and work fine. :)

A quick design for a metric hex key holder for sizes 2, 2.5, 3, 4, 5, and 6 mm. Many of your 3D printers use various size metric hex keys, so I picked up this set of t-handle hex keys from Amazon. They provide good length to get to those hard to reach screws.

The holes for the hex keys are actually 0.5mm oversize to allow you to easily insert and remove the tools. My previous iterations were too tight and the tools were either not going in well or were creating a vacuum on removal.

Designed in Fusion 360, and as usual with my designs, the F360 file is included if you want to play around with it.

Two versions are included, one with sharp corners and one with soft corners (.5mm fillet)

title: Azteeg X5 Mini to Print-Rite DIY mounting adapter w/USB cable clamp

description.text:
My third revision of an adapter to mount an Azteeg X5 Mini board to a Print-Rite DIY printer's controller board mounting holes. The original controller board screws can be used to mount the adapter to the original holes and the Azteeg board can be mounted with M3 screws (I used M3x8 machine screws and it worked fine).

This revision also includes a clamping point for the USB cable. I quickly discovered during the retrofit process that the mini USB connector is not very robust and it takes little cable motion to break the connection. The clamp can be used with zip ties up to 3mm wide to effectively ensure that the USB cable isn't pulled loose. I used some 1mm wide zip ties.

Note that the version in the picture had a slight mistake in the upper right corner, which has been corrected in this print.

This was originally drawn in SketchUp.

description.text: This is a loom for creating rubberband bracelets. It is designed to fit two base plates together for longer projects.  I created this from scratch so that the interconnecting pieces fit together and used Draco155's thing as a guide but that one does not fit together without a lot of filing and the posts break off too easily.  My first attempt was the orange base plate (see photos) but the posts were also too easy to break off, so I enlarged and strengthened the posts so those don't break off as easily.   The purple base plate is the final version (see photo).

I printed this out at .2mm layer height, 4 shells (you want it strong) and 10% infill.  It shouldn't need any sanding - mine fit perfectly.  
I printed two out at a time on my Rep 2, that works well, see the thing file.  I also changed the filament for the posts, I think it adds a bit to make those a contrasting colour; wait for the extruder to stop going around the outer edge of the baseplate then switch colours.

description.text:
Some simple scales for a Kershaw Chill knife. Easy to print, easy to customize.

I included both tip-up and tip-down versions of the left scale so you can carry however you like. There's also both a blank version of the right scale and one that has my logo cut into it. Adding your own graphics is as simple as using your tool of choice to cut or boolean your shape out. Looks great with a filament swap for subtle color variation.

.STEP files are also included to make modifications in CAD programs easier.

Some tips on disassembling/reassembling your knife:

  • Take note of where you put the two screws for the clip. Although they look the same as the others, they are actually a bit longer. Only those two screws will work on the clip, but they will also work on the scales. Be careful that you don't accidentally use them on the scales or you'll have no screws with which to attach your clip.
  • The easiest way to re-assemble the knife is starting on the left side (the side with the clip/liner lock). The pins that hold the handle in place all have flat edges that match up with flat edges in the metal frame. Screw those in to hold your left scale in place, then add the plastic frame spacer, pin, washers, blade, etc.
  • The flat side of the pin goes towards the clip. If you put the domed end towards the clip it might be tough to get in/out of your pocket.
  • The smaller washers go on the clip side. This is important because the larger ones will interfere with the liner lock. For both sets, the copper washer must be the one touching the blade.

Notes:

This is the easiest print ever. No overhangs, no weird orientations. Layer height doesn't matter.

comments.text: make one for the leek please!!
comments.author: alpacaluva

comments.text: The Leek would be tough since it has the SpeedSafe mechanism, but maybe at some point I'll look into it. I have a Leek but find myself reaching for the Chill more often due to its light weight and simple construction.
comments.author: alpacaluva

comments.text:
How did you end up modeling these?
I've tried tracing a liner and scanning it. Scanning the scale itself doesn't work due to the thickness; the scanner picks up shadows and the holes become ellipse shaped. However, my scanned traces are never quite perfect. I looked online to see if anyone else modeled these scales out of curiosity. Kudos.
comments.author: berky93

comments.text: I actually did put the scales (just the plastic scales, not the scales and the metal frame halves) on my flatbed scanner. There were some shadows but I just used the levels controls in Photoshop to make the separation between the plastic and the shadows more evident (plus, since I know the holes are perfectly circular and I can measure their diameter with my calipers I only need to know where to place the circle -- so I could probably do it without adjustments). It was a surprisingly smooth process; would you believe the scales pictured were my first print of the model?

title: Cartridge Holder for Reloaders (.38/9mm and .308 versions)

description.text:
Reloading tray holds 50 .357, .38, 380 or 9MM cartridges. If you reload, these are handy tools to have on your bench.

I just added the STL for a version for the .308 cartridge. This is a longer cartridge that needs a deeper tray.

While these files are sized for one diameter cartridge, it is easy to make them work for any size by just scaling x and y up or down in your slicer. Guesstimate a scaling factor and print the first 8 layers and check for size with your desired cartridge before continuing the print or canceling.

Printer:

I3 clone with Bowden extruder.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

2.5

Infill:

100

Notes:

This is VERY prone to warping so use PLA or similar. ABS will lift the corners every time leading to a very unsatisfactory print. The .308 version will even tend to warp PLA on a heated bed so use a brim or raft and pay attention to adhesion methods. This design is quite strong and rigid so PLA is more than strong enough.

PLA settings were 220 head, 60 bed, 50mm speed, no fan, retract on. .25 layer height works well. Using Cura, my printer needed 3 line walls and 4 layer bottom to get good results.
A bit difficult to remove from the bed. Let it cool completely and work slowly with a putty knife or similar tool.
Designed in Fusion 360 using basic rectangles, dimensions, extrusions and fillets. Fusion360 archive is in the files section.

title: Printable idler, for 2020 v-rail gantry end

description.text:
Printable idler that fits on the end of a 2020 v-rail.
Fits on 2040 v-rail too, if the belt goes through the middle section.
It has "legs" that fit into the t-nut slots, and can be fastened with a M5x10mm screw to the end of the extrution.
Printed with the "legs" standing on the bed, with line-support only touching the bed.

Additional hardware:
2 pc. - 3mm shims (see attached STL, for each side of the bearing)
1 pc. - 625zz bearing
1 pc. - M5x25mm screw (or M5x35mm)
1 pc. - M5x10mm screw (need to tap/thread the end hole in the 2020 for this)
1 pc. - M5 nut

Pictured with the stock Reach 3D endstop arm and M3 screw.
All the hardware in the list is the same as the stock idler uses, so just swap it over.
The M5x10mm screw you can find in the spare parts bag.

comments.text: This is an absolutely excellent mod for the Reach printer.  With this, I have no more worries about the belt slipping off the bearing.

title: Lacie Rugged Macbook Pro Laptop bracket

description.text:
I made this after I picked my Macbook up and the Lacie Rugged Thunderbolt hard drive fell and bent the thunderbolt lead.

Print two of these, slide them on the hard drive and fix it to the top of the screen.

Made for a Macbook Pro 13" Retina but I'm sure it'll fit other Macbooks and laptops but if not feel free to edit it on Tinkercad.

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2UuT0duJAkP

title: 1:100 Breda 20mm Portee (UPDATED 3/23/2017)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Quick chop job to add m_bergman's 20mm Breda AA gun (now without gun shield) to the back of his 1:200 scale CMP truck, which has been scaled to 1:100.

Only "detail" upgrades are some treads cut in the wheels, thinning of certain surfaces to more accurately represent the 15mm scale.
.
Will likely tweak things in the future, but for now I just needed some playable AA.

I did have to tweak the support options to get the gun to print well, but it is doable.

Suggestions are always welcome!

Update 3/22/17 - 15cwt Breda SP added. Can use the 15cwt and 30cwt_nobed with m_bergman's new 20mm Breda gun that includes a gunners seat. The seat will contact the side wall on the 30cwt with bed.
Update 3/23/17 - Added better wheel detail to mimic m_bergman's other wheeled vehicles.

Harry S. McAlpin was the first African-American to attend a U.S. Presidential news conference. While President Roosevelt personally greeted him upon his arrival, McAlpin was still prevented form attending congressional briefings.

Before McAlpin's first Oval Office news conference, though, the association again tried to stop him, warning the room would be so crowded with him in it, he might cause a riot.

McAlpin calmly replied, "That would be a hell of a news story, and I want to be there for that."

description.text:
I recently got a RAVPower Luster Mini 3350mAh. I dont usually like the hassle of plugging things in and out so I made a little dock. This will allow you dock the charger when youre home, and quickly grab it again when you're on the go. It works using the provided usb cable that you get from the product.

You will need a M3x10+ threaded screw to secure the USB inside the dock. There are two additional M3 holes underneath for those who want to secure it to a work desk, nightstand etc. Otherwise, simply use double sided tape to secure.

You can get the little charger here:
https://www.amazon.com/RAVPower-Smallest-Powerful-Portable-External/dp/B00ZZYBAI2/ref=sr_1_10?ie=UTF8&qid=1486740485&sr=8-10&keywords=ravpower+charger

A simply stand to hold the Amazon Fire 7 tablet.

History on why I created this:
I print exclusively with an OctoPi setup. (OctoPrint running on a RaspberryPi.) I love the convenience of being able to have my printer located in another room and to be able to monitor it and start print jobs remotely. The biggest issue I'd run into though, was sometimes when I was at my printer, I had no local interface to stop a failed job, or to start up a new one after removing the old one from the bed. So I decided to add a touch interface to my printer. I picked up an Amazon Fire 7 tablet for $35. I loaded up the a Chrome browser, and point it to my OctoPrint instance. This stand was created to hold the tablet near my printer. I've now got a dedicated touch screen interface for my printer.

This case prints in three parts, the base, an arm which snaps into the base, and a holder which snaps around the tablet, and then snaps onto the top of the arm. (The "Full Assembly" file to print... just demonstrate how it all assembles together.)

Hi!

One of the first things I designed was this little clamp, used to mount the Tarantula frame onto a piece of wood. It's an very easy print, and super useful. By clamping down your printer is becomes much more stable. I even mounted my PSU on the same piece of wood so that my printer is mobile and stable at the same time!

I suggest to print at least 2 of these at the same time, so that the material has time to cool. They are supposed to be printed upright.

There are 2 STL files; the difference is the width of the slot used for the screw. I've used regular wood screws, where 4mm was wide enough.

Please share your experiences and findings if you make one, i'd love to hear (and see) them!

Cheers,
Jordi B
